I've read the books so many many many times and absolutely love then so much and not even 15 minutes into the start of the movie you can tell it's just a pile of dung.We didn't need a narration.What happened to the actual story?!Why was Artemis' Father actually involved?!Why did Artemis already know about the fairies instead of figuring it out himself?WHY WAS COMMANDER ROOT A WOMAN?!?!

I'm not one to ever review a movie. This is the first review I have ever given.It hurts so much to see one of my favorite childhood story be utterly ruined.Everything about it is just awful. They've destroyed the whole story line. The way Artemis is portrayed is so not how he's supposed to be. I don't understand how Eoin Colfer approved this.So much potential flushed down the toilet.This could have been the next big thing. Easily as successful as Harry Potter. The acting too is terrible, don't get me started on Butler.Such a let down. Save yourself the disappointment and don't watch the movie.So much more to rant about but I don't was to relive the disappointment again.

If you read the books, don't watch this movie. It'll ruin the story you loved.
If you didn't read the books, read the books!
And don't watch this movie. It'll ruin the story you will love.
Absolute garbage.

I believe that Artemis Fowl should deserve more credit from the fantastic novel being made into a feature film. Even though Kenneth Branagh has made fantastic films throughout the years, Artemis Fowl may be the worst Disney film equal to A Wrinkle in Time.

While there are plenty of references of 3 storylines from the book series, Artemis Fowl the film, tends to be different yet entertaining. Some pieces are thrown together and some are drawn out with thoughtful precision. All in all, it's not bad. The film could have been much worse. Remember, this film is based off of the book series, not a direct transcript. The film could generate a sequel or limited series that would explore more of the fairy world and plug the holes that many readers are most likely wanting to see from book to film. Only time will tell but Disney has built something that it could definitely build upon. Disney+ looks to be a good home for Artemis Fowl, Butler, Holly, Mulch, Root, Foaly and the rest of the gang.

I have a lot of questions. Who was the antagonist? Why were they angry? Why is the protagonist even involved. Why is he a criminal mastermind? Non of these, and many more questions arose from this film that are left unanswered. Was so bad it was entertaining.

reviews.review_title: Keep Very Low Expectations For Those Who Have Read The Books (duh!)
reviews.content:
Well, I had read all the books and needless to say I was a big fan some 8 years ago. The story was heavily altered so I couldn't quite bring myself to love the movie.
There was a trailer released in 2019 and that trailer was way cooler than this final movie, unfortunately.

reviews.review_title: Kenneth Branagh, I expected better from you.
reviews.content: Yet another travesty. Why does hollywood show readers such disrespect? To take a popular and well loved book and then completely wreck it by changing the characters, the plot and everything that made the series so great is such an insult to both child and adult. Josh Gad was the only highlight in this aberration. I wanted Die Hard with Fairies, I was delivered saccharine.

We just watched Artemis Fowl and please allow me to save you from the same fate. I am just completely lost for words to describe what an absolute pile of rubbish that film was. The story made no sense whatsoever. The characters were all completely underdeveloped and their motivation was baffling. They completely changed Artemis entire personality; he is supposed to be a criminal mastermind, but he barely seems like he could successfully plan to steal a kid's bicycle. He's just a boy who is supposedly super smart, but the only reason you know this is because someone else says it about him. And for some reason instead of taking the wonderful, intricate heist storyline that Colfer wrote in the books, they conjured up a villain from a future book in the series... except they didn't even explain who THAT character was or what their motivation was to do what they did.
I don't think I have ever been as disappointed by an adaptation of a book as I was by this drivel. If you have never read the books, you probably won't understand what the heck is going on. If you have read the books, you will understand just enough to be disgusted by the horrible things they have done to it because you know how much better it should have been.
I usually try to separate a film adaptation from a book and judge it on it's own merits, but the only reason I sort of understood what was happening is because I knew what happened in the books. My husband, who had never read them, was totally confused the entire time.
Friends, I implore you, do not waste 93 minutes of your lives trying to watch this trash.

reviews.review_title: Horrible adaptation. How can this compete with other successful adaptations?
reviews.content: This is by far the worst adaptation of any and all books ever made into movies.I have seen many. LOTR, The Dark Tower, It, The Andromeda Strain, Star Wars, Spiderwick, Harry Potter, Nancy Drew, and so on and so forth...If you are going to make a movie out of a book that has so many elements of the supernatural and preternatural, stick to the book.I could not even get past the first nine minutes... Just including small snippets and micro-nuggets from the original dialogue interspersed within a re-written timeline and depreciative rearrangement of the storyline does not a good movie adaptation make. Mingling the first two books into one, and eliminating Angeline Fowl is NOT how it is done.Those of us who are die-hard Colfer fans of Artemis Fowl and his other works, we say Disney...you screwed-the-pooch on this one. We have been anticipating the release of this movie in hopes of another movie to rival Peter Jackson's adaptation of Tolkien's LOTR series, and expecting something like the Matrix type of cinematography... only to be let down harder than a 747 crash landing.Disney butchered this one... badly. Not going to even try to choke down the rest...
Haven't read the book - så take it for what it is. Entertaining and a no brainer movie.

I have not read the book yet, so I started watching the movie and the movie was so good and funny and very exciting and I would watch Artemis Fowl 2 and I would like to star in the movie. This movie is a good film for Kids, Teens and Adults.

reviews.review_title: A travesty of a film - the worst adaption since Last Airbender
reviews.content:
What the film should be - Die Hard with Faries
What we got - Spy Kids franchise wannabeThis film is absolutely one of the worst adaptations I've ever seen, in fact - its not even really an adaption - instead it reads like someone skimmed the Wikipedia article of Artemis Fowl (the plain English film), then proceeded to binge watch the Spy Kid films before writing this. In case its not clear, I am a big fan of the books, I grew up with them to an extent, I should also be clear that I guess young kids are the target market, but anyway, let the salt begin!The Characters
Artemis FowlWhat he should be: Evil, almost always in a suit and always in controlWhat is he in the film? Irremediably ruined, seen surfing on the Irish waves in the first few moments, turned into a bland kid who is introduced to fairies by his daddy, has no rapport with Butler, seen engaging in hand to hand combat with fairies, takes his sunglasses off and calls Holly a friend in no time.
Character Assassination marks - 10/10ButlerWhat he should be: Suited, booted, awesome, the ultimate bodyguardWhat is he in the film? Irremediably ruined, race-blended for some reason, hardly effective in any scene, holds no human weaponry throughout the entirety of the film, seen crying in several scenes, hugs Artemis Fowl, FML...
Character Assassination marks - 10/10HollyWhat she should be: The first LEP female officerWhat she is in the film? Not the first LEP female officer, has a dumb side-story about her father betraying her people, does not use an awesome LEP gun, constantly looks aimless and stupid, scenes of her flying and saluting are the dumbest thing, calls Artemis Fowl friend, oh make it stop...
Character Assassination marks - 9/10Commander RootWhat HE should be: Cigar chewing police boss with a mean attitude and a secret heart of goldWhat he is the film: The magnificent dame Judi Dench doing a hilarious Irish accent and wearing emerald green, never smokes a cigar.
Character Assassination marks - 12/10Other CharactersFoley - Should be the fairy version of Q, brilliant, paranoid and seen wearing a tin-foil hat. Is none of these things but watching the centaur effects had mean in gales of laughter.
Mulch Diggums - A completely unnecessary narrator but probably the most accurately captured character from the books. Character Assassination marks - 6/10
Briar Cudgeon - I'm not going to either bother
Artemis Fowl Snr - Colin Farrall as the doting father and art-collector who teaches little Arty-Warty all about the fairies and the people. Does not get kidnapped by the Russian mafia in the Bay of Kola. Is most certainly not a criminal mastermind
Juliet Butler - 21 in the books and generally awesome. Race-bended, turned into a teen side-kick and useless for the movie purposes except the demographics.
Angeline Fowl - A crucially important character from the book, completely AWOL in this adaptionWhat else is not in the film?
A cool opening in VietnamThe Fairy BookAcornsMagic (lets be fair, its hardly in it)'I don't even like lollipops'Butler in a suit of amour with a mace taking on a troll (among many other things)Criminal mastermindsGuns, explosions,I digress, but at least they added a magical magufin (the AXIOM) which everyone is after, and loads of fancy CGI (some of it quite stylish and cool), the time stop is initially cool but I don't really 'get' what is going on at the end, its very stupid and confusing (I mean, forget how cool and technical it is in the book, remember Santa?).I'm exhausted now, I can't wait for the YouTube videos covering this, bravo Disney, you took a beloved franchise with great potential for smart, family entertainment and trashed it so completely it will be remembered only along with the other stalwarts of Eragon, Last Airbender, Hungry Cities and so forth.

I'll start by saying that I had no idea this movie was based on a book. That being said, I though this movie had potential. The beginning and the middle weren't bad, but the ending was completely lacking. Overall disappointing and left me feeling very unsatisfied.

reviews.review_title: Gave up after half an hour
reviews.content: Wanted to give it the benefit of the doubt but after half an hour I couldn't bear it anymore. Boring exposition, lacklustre acting and average sfx. Certainly won't be finishing it and really glad I haven't paid a cinema fee to watch it!

reviews.review_title: Waste of everyone's time and effort
reviews.content: Please stay away, do not even try to watch. This thing is an abomination and i curse anyone and everyone who has anything to do with creating it.

I don't know the source material, but I doubt that it revolves around a character dressed as Hagrid who is used as a narrator throughout and who makes terrible ad-libs, as if he's some kind of comic genius.Speaking of Hagrid, the goblins look like they were recruited from Harry Potter and toward the end of the film there are Dementor-looking characters I didn't even try to figure out.This is a confused mess -- like calling all the food at the bottom of a restaurant dish bin "Dinner." Director Kenneth Branagh should be horribly embarrassed by this mess. Does he have some horrible grudge against Disney that he would scar his career to cost them millions?

I could write pages about how bad it was. not only did it feel like they shoved the main charters and a few plot points from the books in a blender and then added their own bs for the rest but I don't think it could be a good stand-alone movie although I am biased as a huge fan of the books. if this seems at all interesting to you just check out the books instead and if you have already read them don't waste your time on this like I did, all I got out of it was yelling at the tv for over an hour.

This movie LOOKS fabulous. I mean the cinematography and graphics and all that is just stunning. But they changed all the key plot points of the story we love, and I found the new plot a bit difficult to sink my teeth into. It has the characters we love, but the changes are difficult to accept. Why not make the movie FROM THE BOOK? The suave coolness and sheer genius of Artemis, that mystery and wonder that I felt reading the first book of "who is this kid!?!?" - it was absolutely deflated by the movie introducing him as just a kid trying to figure out what happened to his dad who by the way left just like yesterday. And meanwhile Josh Gad as Mulch is giving a step by step play by play narrative which is supremely unnecessary and a bit awkward. But again...it LOOKS so good, which almost makes it worse because I'm just finding myself supremely upset at the lack of realized potential that it could have been.

reviews.review_title: Exceeded expectations but only loosely based on ths books
reviews.content: After reading the review I was expecting an awful movie. But this was far from it. The movie is BASED on the books, like Harry potter movies are, and that's where the majority of the bad reviews come from as the actors are a lot different form what's detailed in the books
Not good at all................yeah it is not a good movie

This movie is way better than a 4.2. It had a great story line to it, beautiful visual effects and the acting was great too. If you like supernatural/fairytale stories as I do, you will like this movie. I rated this a 10 just bc of all the negative reviews. If it weren't so poorly rated, I would rank it at least a 6.

I grew up reading these books! They inspired my love for the fantasy genre and provided my love for learning and wit. But this movie was plain aweful. When I heard Disney was making this movie, I was so excited. But then as I watched, the truth became clear that it wouldn't be even close to my bar for a passable movie.Let me explain exactly what's wrong with this movie:The movie was allover horrible. The whole movie felt like it was catering to young children who can't wait around for plot to progress. Each scene jumps from one to the next without any suspense or sense of urgency and planning. The whole movie had an aura of being rushed and shambled together. Nothing truely felt cohesive. Each event happened back to back to back with no repreave or build up.Artemis Fowl is supposed to be a genius with a plan for everything. And even when something goes wrong? He's got the wit to find a way out. But in this movie, he comes off more like a whiney and pretentious brat. The only recognizable part of this character is the iconic suit and sunglasses.Holly Short didn't feel like her spunky self, and only came across as ditzy and mediocre at best. She wasn't this strong character that she was in the books, and it truely felt like a crime to her character.They genderswapped commander Root, one of my favorite characters. I love Judy Dench as an actress, but she added nothing to the character and felt like a cheap virtue-signalling substitute. She felt very 2D and shallow as a character, which made me very upset. But that doesn't even get to what made me the most angry, oh no.They F'd up Buttler. My hands down favorite character was broken down into the butt of the jokes. They reffused to pay homage to the book and insisted that "Anyone who reffered to him as Buttler would surely regret it" and proceeded to call him Dom the entire movie. Normally, that wouldn't be too bad. But they also made him into the emotional character of the movie, which isn't nessicarily bad if his character wasn't supposed to be someone who we know and loved because he had the emotions of a rock. The man's emotions in the books were so complex and had to be earned to witness. But in this trainwreck of a movie, they even gave him the painstaking "I'm not gunna cry" line.-They made Opal more comparable to the lovechild of Skeletor and Dr. Evil.She was evil for evil's sake and no more. They even gave her the generic "I'm going to take over the world" schpeel.But there is one thing I can say that's good about the movie. The special effects were neat. But that's it. Everything else made me want to carve my soul out with a dull fork. Please don't watch this movie, go pick up the book

reviews.review_title: Large negatives outweigh decent aspects to a disjointed 5.
reviews.content: So to start, this film does have some things going for it. There is generally good production value throughout. It is visually appealing and looks cool in its, limited, locations. And, there is generally solid acting; none are amazing, yet none terrible and Artemis is a sometimes compelling lead.Now for the much greater negative portions of this movie. I can't hate on the plot because of the books plot since I never read the book(s). But, there are issues with character development, plot transitions, and emotional weight; however, I will not dive too deep into these since all share the same root issue: the rushed feeling of the movie. The story is compressed into a measly 1.5 hours and its painfully ruinous. Characters are supposed to capture our emotions and attachment after only a few interactions; far to little time and dialogue is invested into making the audience care. As a result, scenes that should hol weight don't, and you feel little to no emotions when you should. The plot itself is only decent and falls prey to many clichés and predictable turns, but the compressed, rushed nature exasperates many problems. Jumping from scene to scene not only made it hard to connect with the characters, it made the plot feel disjointed and hard to follow. Locations suddenly shift, plans come into existence, and bonds are formed with far too little screen time and dialogue to make sense of it all, again removing some of the weight from scenes.Overall, good aspects carry this film to its minimum score and it is heavily weighed down by its negatives. But, against all odds, it was mildly entertaining throughout and mostly held my attention.

reviews.review_title: If you read and TRULY loved the books...
reviews.content:
YOU WILL HATE THIS MOVIE.I am absolutely disgusted at how they butchered the books. Beyond fuming. They murdered my childhood in the name of Disney!Let me try to list some of the ways in which they committed this atrocity against the books (contains spoilers, and in no particular order):Artemis Fowl would never go surfing! He was not an athletic child. He would not be surfing, or hoverboarding or whatever that thing was. He rarely participated in physical activity, letting Butler do the heavy lifting, while he used mere intelligence. He would be absolutely USELESS in physical combat.In the books, Arty's father was a master criminal, but not a particularly great one. And he had NOTHING to do with the fairies. Artemis believed in the fairies. He tracked down a sprite in the human world, and gained access to the secret book. He created a computer program which cracked the fairy code. He was trying to uphold and restore the criminal name of Fowl by pulling off the biggest heist of all time: stealing fairy gold. His father doesn't come into actual play until book two, and he has nothing to do with the fairy world. He was kidnapped by plain old humans.
They rewrote Gnomish. Yes, I can still read the fairy code. And they changed the characters for the letters.
Angeline Fowl is NOT dead in the books. She is in severe emotional distress, and out of her head over the loss of her husband. She is delusional, drifting in and out of the past and present, barely recognizing her son. Artemis carefully keeps her condition hidden, so he can continue with his criminal dealings unchecked. She plays a very large role in Artemis's character development.Juliet Butler is Domovoi's sister, not niece, and she's 16. She wants to be a professional wrestler.A Butler NEVER reveals his or her first name to his charge/employer. A Butler's first name is only revealed when they are dying or dead.Commander Julius Root was male in the books. Constantly angry, turned purple in the face when angry (earning the nickname Beetroot), and was infamous for smoking noxious fungus cigars. Holly Short was the ONLY FEMALE IN THE ENTIRE HISTORY OF THE LEP! By making Root female and adding other female officers to the force, they completely invalidated Holly as a character, and her mentor/mentee relationship with Commander Root. So much of Holly's motivation comes from her desire to prove herself as the first ever female LEP officer. Holly's father was not a traitor. Root rides Holly much harder than the other officers because he is trying to help her prove herself, and keep her ever precarious position on the force. He endorses her repeatedly, as the first and only female officer. He is like a father figure to her.WHAT THE HELL IS AN ACULOS?!? Did not exist in the books. And Opal Koboi doesn't come into play until book 4.Mulch Diggums is supposed to only BARELY pass as human. They made dwarves way too human. He also enters the house through the wine cellar. They completely cut, changed, or vagued up other dwarf abilities. Beard hair that can be shaped, and then holds shape when plucked, perfect for picking locks. It also acts as antennae, picking up vibration underground, a kind of dwarf sonar. Dwarf spit, which hardens and glows in the dark. Dwarves are also EXTREMELY sun sensitive. Dwarves are able to absorb moisture through their pores, and can essentially spider man over/up any surface due to this ability. Mulch escapes by faking his own death, slipping the contact into the eye of a rabbit, killing it and faking a cave in.Cudgeon joins with Opal AFTER he is humiliated during the failed rescue attempt of Holly Short. Artemis succeeds, by successfully kidnapping a fairy, and negotiating for Holly's return. He receives fairy gold as ransom, and successfully escapes the bio bomb, out witting the fairies at almost every turn.Holly was supposed to be at Tara performing the ritual to refresh her magic, by burying an acorn under the light of the full moon. She was captured because she was unable to use magic. As the books put it, she was not, "running hot."Butler takes on the troll alone, and almost dies for it. Holly ACCIDENTLY heals him, and he then takes down the troll, after Holly fights it. Holly swoops in and saves him, after escaping by tricking Juliet and using the mesmer effect on her.Artemis and crew escape the time freeze and bio bomb by doing the impossible: falling asleep. The fairies planned to kill them all and take the gold back once Holly was recovered. Humans, fairies, living creatures cannot fall asleep when in a time freeze. Not if they were awake when it is implemented. Artemis and his associates escape the time freeze and bio bomb (which decimates ALL living things) by taking sleeping pills. He used his mother Angeline, to test the theory when the time freeze was first activated.These are just a few main points. If you loved the books, don't waste your time on this movie. If you've never read the books, have fun. Just know, this movie has little to nothing to do with the wonderful series written by Eoin Colfer

reviews.review_title: What a crying shame - murdered a brilliant book
reviews.content: Possibly the worst adaptation from a book I've ever seen. The books are very funny and quirky and unique with a sharp edge and a nice dose of silliness, aptly described as 'die hard but with fairies'. This film was a sirupy, bland, tacky, cheesy mess that would have seemed out of date if played on CBBC in the 1980s (don't know if cbbc existed then but you get the picture). This could have been the start of a brilliant and hilarious fantasy franchise that really championed the Irish humour and folklore. Instead it was a catastrophe.Artemis himself: in the book a cold hearted anti hero, who at 12 years old, only ever wears a suit and outwardly feels no empathy and scorns at any sort of emotion. Only starts to soften in book two, but only a little. And an actively practicing high level criminal. In the film, a playful kid who loves surfing and outward bound activities and sentimentally listening to his father reading him fairytales - and who is appalled when the TV news calls his father a criminal.And aside from that so many things, why is Mulch tall and with a height complex? Where did that come from? And why do they all become friends so fast? There's generally a lot more narky taking the piss and being rude to each other in the books, replaced by doe eyed, heart warming long looks and emotional music here.The main problem, why didn't they just adapt the first book, rather than try and squeeze half baked elements of the second book? The evil child genius discovers the existence of the fairies and plots to kidnap one of them to steal their secrets, he does so and there's a frenzied rescue mission. That is more than enough. Instead they added in an honourable father rescue mission and introduced a half baked version of Opal Koboi (what a waste of a cracking villain introduced in book 2, the vain, high pitched narcissist beautiful pixie turns into an anonymous hooded villain with a distorted voice)These books are brilliant. Get your kids to read them, read them to your kids, read them yourself as an adult, such a shame they butchered them in this catastrophe of a film that could have been so much better!

reviews.review_title: What a mess. What a waste.
reviews.content: Movies can be inspired by the books they're based on without copying them outright. I get that.This movie though. Just...wow.Artemis Fowl is a complete departure from the books. Fine. Ok. The trailers gave me a heads up on that so all the movie needed to do was be good. And by "good" I mean be entertaining and coherent.But it wasn't. It can't. And it only has itself to blame.Abandoning the books' arcs meant completely rewriting the story: People's relationships, their motives, their arcs, and their major plot points. This might have been fine, except it comes off feeling as though they're rushing to cram several stories into this one movie.If they were planning to stick to the source material, I could kind of understand why they might do that; after all, the movie would probably be seen by people who'd read the books, and they'd forgive the plot holes and badly done exposition because their knowledge of the books would fill in the gaps.But this movie's writers and directors knew this movie wasn't for people who'd read the books, because they were the ones who rewrote and directed it! So the movie must be for people who are completely unfamiliar with the books. Right?Except it can't be for them because the movie's idea of world building and story telling is to rush from one character introduction and one situation to the next... as if the viewer already knows who these characters are and what they're doing, so let's get on with it thank you very much.So who's this movie for? It's directed with a nod and wink as though it's made specifically for people who love the books. But it abandoned the source material, so fans of the books are just as in the dark as people meeting these characters for the very first time.It's not for kids. There's just to much new information to absorb in such a short amount of time. So we're back to the same problem of making a movie as though it's an homage to the books, but making the creative choice to make the movie nothing like the books.Could've been great. Could've at least been FUN. But it was neither. It was a mess.In trying to make a movie for everybody, they made a movie for nobody.

reviews.review_title: Lucky for this "film" you can't give 0 stars...
reviews.content: My twin girls loved and I mean LOVED these books. It literally the one thing that they could agree on. This is the second: WHY?! How did this get made? Did they read the books? I mean, any part of any book? We kept watching in the hopes it would improve. Obviously, that didn't happen. Disney is so fortunate that covid hit because this would have been a total box office bomb. The "story" was all of the place. There was no reason to care about any of the characters. Especially the character of Artemis. He is such an arrogant jerk through out. Stuff happens here, just because. There's no explanation as to what going on other than they "tell" us that it is. It is so completely absurd that I may have hurt myself rolling my eyes so much. Case and point: When Artemis' father gets kidnapped, Artemis figured out that clues must be in this journal because of a bedtime story that his dad reads to him every night. (Not past tense, present tense) But just before that, we are told that the dad is almost always away...Point number two: We are told that Artemis is a genius and never actually shown that he is. There is no lead up to this claim. Which in turn, makes him out to be this pretentious, condescending, know-it-all. Last point: How and why does the digger dig into the ground only to reach the second floor and arbitrarily find the safe?? Ugh!!! There are plenty more - tonnes more. It is so nonsensical and convoluted. If I payed at the cinema to see this, there's no telling what I would have said here...My advice? Don't! Just................Don't!!

reviews.review_title: Shambolic and ill-conceived from beginning to end.
reviews.content: Whilst I'm a huge fan of the books, I understand that Hollywood can't always convert literature to the Silver Screen. This......atrocity is no Artemis Fowl movie, and is painful to view for a multitude of reasons.Characters are introduced with barely any screen time and the flimsiest of narratives, most are pointless loose ends that only serve as jumping points for a sequel, and things like character development or relationship-building has been tossed to the wayside - but with nothing in its place. Core characters have been shattered and mutilated beyond recognition, and it spoils the essence of Artemis Fowl Jr. in the most casual manner.A key facet of Artemis is his arrogance, his ego. He is a driving force, master manipulator, socially inept, physically useless. Whatever wimpy, sporting, foot-stamper I just exposed my eyeballs to was *nothing* like that, and that's a major catastrophe for not just this movie but the entire franchise. Book-wise, Artemis learns about fairy folk independently. He is obsessed with finding his father and funding further research into discovering them. He is an uncaring, unsympathetic character who steals a copy of the Fairy holy book in order to exploit the Fairy people, beat them at their own game, and steal a metric tonne of gold for the purpose of reinflating his wallet. His father was a cold, hardened, high-profile criminal who never gave Artemis as much as a supporting pat on the back - and all of these character aspects are what made the book phenomenal. The entire series deals with character development within adolescence and early adulthood, but also the notion that regardless of how much brain power you have, Butler will not always be around to save him, and this you need a support network.Which brings me to another point - potentially trivial but bothers me massively nonetheless. Butlers name is Domovoi. Artemis does not know this. In Book3 (The Eternity Code) his name is only revealed when literally dying in Artemis' arms. This was a huge and emotional moment, that makes NO sense now thanks to it being revealed right off the bat. For a movie that was practically screaming "SEQUEL SEE THERE WILLBE A SEQUEL ITS NOT OVER SEQUEL SEQUEL", they sure did trash a whole load of plotline and development that could have been sequel material.Aside from the glaring plot disparities, unenthusiastic performances, total lack of on screen chemistry or emotion, and dreadful CGI (lookin' at you, Mulch) - the whole movie makes limited sense, the aesthetics are basic and repetitive, the score is simply filler and is as bland as plasticine, and humour is lacking even I'm funny moments.It's a good job I never have to subject myself to the tripe and drivel that spewed forth from my television, and I'm confident in saying that there wont be another one to follow. Rank from start to finish.

A small introduction to understand my high expectations:
I have read the books as a kid and I was super enthusiastic about the story line. This Christmas, I was back to my parents place, and while passing next to the bookcase, I got a glimpse of the first book. Then I decided to read it again just to have something to pass my time back home. I ended up reading the first two books of the series in three days and I enjoyed every moment of it (I am 30 years old).
So you can imagine my excitement when in January I noticed that there was a movie coming up from Disney. I saw the trailer and it really looked like they had done a good job. Yesterday, I watched the movie and from the first minute I had this feeling that this will not go well. Indeed, through the whole movie, one question was always on my mind: "Why?".
First of all, the story-line has been altered quite a lot in comparison to the books. While this could generally be accepted since it is a book adaptation, it seems that they just added a lot of unessential information which just puzzled the viewer to understand what was happening in 1.5 hour running time. There was no build-up of the story, the narration of Mulch was at least annoying and unnecessary, the acting was at best mediocre, while there was a constant try to present clever and fun puns (which admittedly they managed a couple of times).
Generally, it seemed like a movie that they decided to invest on the CGI and not the plot and actors. Even the CGI I didn't really find it to fulfil really high standards.
I don't think that my discomfort was coming from the fact that I have read the books. I believe that even someone that had no clue of the story and watched the movie, could only say that this was just a really bad movie. I cannot help to feel really disappointing, as I feel that they took a story with the highest potential and basically ruined it.

reviews.review_title: Not so bad if, you haven't read the books

The further the movie is from the source material, the more frustrated the audience will be. My ten-year-old son was terribly frustrated by this movie because it did not follow some very basic details from the books (those have been listed in detail by other reviewers). For the rest of us, this was a fun, if juvenile, tale of magic, fairies, and mystery. It won't be a household favorite, but it was easier to follow than any lovers of the books believe it was. If you've read the books, prepare to be very disappointed. If you haven't, you probably will enjoy it well enough.

reviews.review_title: Bad adaptation of a decent book.

The original storyline was altered and simplified so much that the movie feels like a parody. The action scenes were stupid, confusing and pointless.Another bad feature (which can also be seen in other in modern american movie adaptations) is that they replaced some of the original and well-know characters with african-american versions. That is, in the original books, Butler was Russian-Japanese, and his little sister Juliet (who was 4 years older than Artemis) had blond hair and blue eyes. This kind of changes makes the move to feel something like a mockery of the original books.

They could have had an amazing movie on their hands. The books are great and I loved them when I was younger. reviews.review_title: I thought I hated it because I'm a fan of the books...
reviews.content:
I thought I hated it because I'm a fan of the books - have been for nearly 20 years - but the more I think about it, the more I get genuinely angry thinking about this film.Sure it missed some essential parts from the book: "the ritual", "the book", everything that happened in Ho Chi Minh, Angeline Fowl, Etc. (Not to mention the fact that Butler would never allow anyone to refer to him as "Dom") but that's not why I hated it.The acting was objectively bad. I realise the kids are young, but that's not an excuse. It was as though it was their first time reading the script.The characters made decisions that no real person would ever make. Holly Short goes from captive to friend in a matter of seconds.No explanation as to the boundaries/capabilities of magic. No explanation as to how the time stop works or why it's supposed to be such a big deal when it breaks.We were supposed to be invested when a character looks like they're on the brink of death, but we've been given no reason to care and no reason to think they're actually going to die.The book gave plenty of explanations as well as more realistic motivations for all of the actions taken.This film has inspired me to go back and reread the series, as a way of purging the memory of this insult to the books.This is the worst film I can remember seeing.I went into this film wanting to love it, especially since I, like many fans, have been waiting nearly 20 years for it. The first 15 minutes was awful. And it only got worse.The people at Disney need to learn how to tell a story, and maybe take a writer/director who cares about the source material.So many iconic moments were missing.
"Stay back human: you don't know what you're dealing with."

There is a real problem in reviewing a book to movie adaptation if you are familiar with the source material. I have read the original book, and the rest of the series, and they are all witty and tightly plotted.Eoin Colfer's own description of the book was "Die Hard with Fairies" and that does nicely explain the fun feel of the novel
The film is none of these things.
It is obviously very difficult to adapt a book for a film, the issues of length alone can be insurmountable, however, that isn't really an excuse for mashing (I think) three of the original books together, then completely changing the character of the protagonist (books - think Lex Luthor in a world without Superman. Film, goodness knows what!) The character of Artemis' father doesn't appear in the first book, presumably they got Colin Farrell so decided to shoehorn him in for no good reason. The fact he had absolutely nothing to do can be glossed over, right?
So, really difficult to review the film without bemoaning the evisceration of the source material. However, there are specific weaknesses. Artemis himself, I'm sure Robert Shaw's relative is a fine actor, but given what he had to work with he was awful here. Holly should have been cast with an adult and digitally made smaller. All due respect the actor isn't mature enough to catch the nuances. Foaly, the centaur, also has nothing to do, and the centaur CGI was done better in Hercules the Legendary Journeys twenty odd years ago. If you feel your film needs an interminable narration throughout you've probably messed up the script.
Dame Judi Dench, as always, was good.
If you liked the books - Avoid. Same goes for if you don't know the source material. Luckily it's streamed so it shouldn't waste too much of your money if you catch it by accident.

reviews.review_title: Different than books but still entertaining family movie
reviews.content: I actually watched the whole movie last night with 12 and 14 year old who are avid AF fans for 7 years. I haven't read the books myself but listen to several as audiobooks while shuttling kids around. I have watched it at 142" home theater with decent audio. Let me share what an average viewer who is not AF superfan can think about this movie.At the time when there is a complete drought of new movies this was actually fairly entertaining film for me and my kids. I would rate it 3.5-4 stars. Definitely something family can watch together for relaxing evening without violence, innuendoes or bad language. The movie is 135 min long which is just right. The fact that the story is narrated by Munch is weird and somewhat distracting but explained at very end. The story is easy to follow and simplified from the books (i found the books somewhat weird and it took my a while to figure out the book world).The acting is fine, even though the creators missed some opportunities to make the characters, especially AF and Butler more memorable. The special effects are well done and the fairy world as well as AF mansion have high production values. We actually quite liked the characters of Holly Short and Munch, even though Munch's portrayal is too close to HP Haggrid.My kids who have AF memorized immediately commented that the story is different from the book but that didn't stopped them from enjoying the movie. We had several good laughs, there was some good suspense and action for them (the troll scene, the final battle) and after the movie was over we had goo discussion what was different from the books and what worked well and not so well. We are hoping there will be a sequel as there is not enough characters and stories like this for kids.Finally, if you have Disney+ you get this movie at no additional cost and its production value, story telling and world portrayal is much better and original than most other traditional Disney movies. Give it a chance and watch it with open mind and you may just find you will enjoy it.

reviews.review_title: Josh Gad was the only good thing about this movie
reviews.content:
While I have never read the books, I went in with high hopes for this movie. With leads Josh Gad, Dame Judi Dench, and Colin Farrell, a huge fan following for the books, and what seemed to be a really cool new universe to discover, I was pretty excited we were going to get to see it on Disney Plus for free!All of this being said, the production value, effects, cast, and music are the only reason this gets an extra star. You can tell this could have been an amazing story, but the lack of exposition, storyline, and character development are too glaring to be overlooked.As someone who cried at the drop of a hat and can develop empathy for almost any character with even a small bit of good character development, I was shocked by my own reaction when a character that I should have cared about literally died and I felt nothing. I didn't tear up, didn't have an ounce of emotion for him. What should have been an impactful moment and an amazing celebration right after, meant nothing.Major holes and issues:
Development between Artemis and Dom. They seemingly have a Bruce Wayne/Alfred relationship, but we wouldn't know for sure because they're not developed at all.Artemis is very well trained, he and Dom take on an entire fairy squad in their own. How? How and when was he trained? We just assume he's trained because Dom is trained? This literally could have been solved by a two minute montage in the morning of Dom waking up Artemis and saying, "Let's go, time for daily training." And training being interrupted by the phone call from the bad guy.Artemis says "We need the suit". The suit has never been previously revealed and we don't know what it does. Is the suit magic? Does the suit have magical powers? What?The fairy world's feelings towards Holly. We have one guy in the whole movie who expresses animosity towards Holly, yet when she gets an assignment and praise at the end, you can tell that's impactful for her.... but it isn't for us. Again, could've had a moment where she goes for a salute and no one salutes back, or a group of fairies calls her a traitor in the street scene.Why does Artemis asking Holly "Can I trust you?" And Holly responding with what she said warrant him removing his glasses and blindly trusting her? You could've had her have a breakdown and cry over her father and saying how she wants to prove his innocence and him feeling and understanding that and then sharing his story too. Leaving his glasses on until after they share a moment when Holly saves Dom, which also could have happened and been another impactful moment. EMOTION. MOTIVATION. DEVELOPMENT.Juliet. Zero purpose. Served absolutely no purpose. Why was she there? To do the butler duties Dom is supposed to do? Because all she did was bring people food. And the fairies just let her hang out at the tower during the whole battle. Convenient.Why did they say Dom hated being called a butler, but there's never a pay off for that? Diggum knew that, great opportunity for a comedic moment. We got nothin.There were so many other issues, too many to name, but they dropped the ball on this movie. I get this was a movie aimed at kids, but as so many adults read this book and fell in love too, this was really a disservice to them. Feel bad for the fans of the book...

reviews.review_title: Most tragic waste of potential I've ever seen
reviews.content:
For a child, I'd say it's cringe-inducing but relatively entertaining.It was like they took a class on Story Theory and mashed in all of the elements in too short a time. Sloppy and rushed writing and directing. CGI hidden in shadow a lot of the time. Time was a huge restraint, but so much garbage could have been cut.It's nothing like the books, obviously. Some of the changes had so much potential, and others made it worse.One of the greatest tragedies the movie tried sooooo hard to adopt was Eoin Colfer's seamless mesh of ancient Irish fairy tale magic and science fiction. The movie's compromise was to talk a lot about magic at the beginning with gorgeous shots of Ireland and Irish music, contrasted with Artemis randomly surfing in modern gear. Or, if they talked about magic, it was in hushed voices filled with awe, which actually undermined them as strong characters we could take seriously.Artemis Fowl II, intentions: a professional criminal mastermind, but more likable than in the books
Result: Artemis is no hardened criminal. In fact, he commits 2 crimes total, both to rescue someone he cares about. Also, just kidding, they totally weren't going for professional, unless that means wearing a suit and calling people. He gives lines that no self-respecting child would, like when his dad is teaching him about fairies: "All I want...is to believe in YOU." While Colfer's Artemis has vampire-pale skin and shuns society, apparently an outdoorsy, surfing Artemis was predicted to be more likable.Domovoy Butler, Artemis' best friend and bodyguard: goes by "Butler" in the books to indicate a sense of natural professionalism. In the movie, he goes by "Dom" to...indicate their close friendship...?Mulch Diggums, intentions: the comic relief and mysterious narrator.
Results: 80% of his jokes fell flat, 5% of which were cringey. But that still leaves 20% decent content. He had a confusing role trying to convey mystical secrets and comedy, so either you couldn't take him seriously or couldn't laugh.Artemis Fowl I, father, intentions: give the movie a more clear plot outline than the books and provide a more dynamic familial role than an ailing mother.
Result: clear plot conflict successful! Took authority from Artemis as being the man of the house. Awkward, unclear relationship.Holly Short, intentions: epic, pretty fighter and Artemis' arch frienemy
Results: fight scenes good, but there was no reason for Artemis to make himself an enemy. As one of my favorite book characters, she wasn't completely ruined, and it was nice to see her come to life on screen.I don't even know why they introduced Butler's little sister other than to have another POC in the film. Making Commander Root a woman was another easy score for diversity, although it really did work better than the disaster everything else was.You know Chekhov's saying: "If in the first act you have hung a pistol on the wall, then in the following one it should be fired"? There were dozens of proverbial guns that were immediately fired. A missing fairy journal written by his father... I literally texted my bf, "All we need are a music box and a key." 2 minutes later, with the help of an encoded song, they find the journal. Also, an object is called, "a skeleton key to the entire universe." Yeah, not dramatic at all. I can only thank heaven that there was not a romantic interest.

Please spare yourself and don't watch....I am a big fan even my name suggest it was super looking forward to watch this but its simply garbage...While the set design is pretty good, the storyline is Trash and i mean it, there simply is no story I suggest you go read the books first. They are worth more your time than this. The voice over goes on for almost the whole movie.Simply put this TITLE had the potential to be ranked among the top block busters the likes of Harrypoter,Narnia.....such a shame. you simply can not connect the plot,parts of the trailer are not shown on the brighter side we got to see Mulch Diggums at work that is Gold.

Even taking aside the fact that this movie is not even trying to be an Artemis fowl movie, it is sadly really bad. The main issue comes from its pace : the movie is going so fast between scenes and situation that it lefts absolutely no room for exposition, character development or consistent story. As a movie, it is barely enjoyable.On the adaptation side, I do not think they could fail more to get what Artemis Fowl is all about. The book is based on the very simple fact that Artemis is, actually, the bad guy. He extorts and kidnaps fairies, showing no emotion except when it comes to his mom. the version of Artemis we get in this movie is so badly written it's so hard to watch.I can give credit to few scenes such as Holly leaving Haven City and fighting the Troll. But that's 3 minutes of it. Foaly is useless and lacks the humour He is supposed to have. Mulch Diggums however has some nice moments, but damn the visual effects are not on point.As always the story is the key of a movie, and here, it's pure garbage : the fact that they needed a character to do the narrator during the whole movie is an admission of their failure.Kenneth Branagh shows that book adaption is not his strongest point.Disney, please, stop books adaptations, thank you.

reviews.review_title: Its like a movie from the sparknotes of the books
reviews.content: This movie could have been done far more effectively with half the budget if they had stuck with the books. Instead they've made this atrocity. Terrible movie and terrible adaption of a great book (from a filmmaking, casting, and story adaptation perspective)

First off let me say that KB is an accomplished and excellent director and actor.
What in the name of God was he thinking of here 🤑 ??
Eoin Colfer's book is an innovative and fantastic read, this movie suffers from a bad script, terrible acting and the the worst case of let's wrap it up in a Disney style fashion. I listened to an interview with Eoin on Irish Radio today and he feebly tried to defend the movie having sold the rights about 20years ago . Be careful what you wish for and get a good lead actor ! Young Shaw is the Grandson of Hollywood actor Robert Shaw proving that acting is not hereditary.

I loved the books when I was younger, and was looking forward to the film, I purposefully didn't watch any of the trailers in case it disappointed...
I really wish I did so I didn't have to watch that...
Artemis is cold, calm and collected, always wore a suit, was always thinking ahead.
The first book it was he that discovered the fairy civilization, not his father or his family, his dad was missing which drove his mother insane and she lived in the attic room.
Artemis wanted to steal the fairy gold, not the arcos or whatever mcguffin it was in the film.
Opal wasn't in the first book, or at least if she was it was briefly mentioned as a rival to Foaly.
Artemis didn't know Butler's first name until about the 3rd book when he temporarily died.
Juliet was butler's 16-18 year old sister, not his 12 year old niece.
What happened to Holly to suddenly trust Artemis in the film? Did I miss something? She was all hostile towards him, they had a 30 second conversation and then she trusted him? I don't even...
And don't get me started on Mulch... Described as a short fuzzy creature, not a 6ft tall guy... Also, if I remember, Holly was described as barely being 5ft tall...
The story it's self had vague matching points to the first book...All in all, don't watch this.

Ok, this must be the worst movie I have ever seen. And I've seen a lot of bad ones.
There is almost no connection to the books, witch I love! They can not have read more than the cower of the book and a list of the names that are in it. There is so many big mistakes that it is painfull to watch.Just a few of the errors I fuond:
1 Artemis is not atletich at all!
2 Butler is Eurasian!
3 Butler is called Butler and Atremis does not get to know his name until a later book.
4 The therapy scene is from book 2
5 Mulch Is not the narrator, and would not be revealing anything about magic to humans.
6 Artemis Sr got lost in the russian sea, and was not kidnapped by a fairy, but Russian mafia.
7 Root is a man, not a woman.
8 Artemis knows his dad is a criminal and he is one himself.
9 Artemis Sr knows nothing about faries or magic.
10 There is no shootout at Fowl Manor between LEP and Butler. And Artemis would rather be inside than out in the field.
11 That is not how a dwarf berd works.
12 The troll fight is all wrong.
13 Mulch escapes from inside the house and is presumed dead.
14 Artemis Sr is not rescued until a later book.
The whole movie was terrible even if you look past all deviations from the book. And I really hope this will be the last attempt from Disney at the wonderful series.

reviews.review_title: Stop making drama, it's good entertaining fun!
reviews.content: Everyone seems to have hitched onto the slating bandwagon here...but I've not read the books and based on that subjective opinion, I enjoyed the film as did my kids of various ages. I only made it 30 minutes. It's ALLLLLL over the place. Who on earth watched this cut of the movie and gave it a green light?!?! It isn't a story, it's pieces of a story. Can we see a cut with everything they took out? Maybe then I would know what in the world is going on.

Don't get ne wrong. I like who they got for holly I thought she played her well. The kid they got for artemis was good too. But butler and juliet was terrible. Juliet was suppose to be 17 not 12. Not to forget commander root was suppose to be a man holly is suppose to be the first female in the LEP. I can stand combing the movies I get it but atleast get the character correct. Thats what pisses me off the most. I'm not saying it wouldn't be a good movie if I didn't love the books I'm just disappointed that they couldn't do a better job with as long as we waited for it.

reviews.review_title: Wow! Just like Percy Jackson, they totaled this series
reviews.content:
Seriously, there are a LOT of changes I could have lived with:
Root being female (basically Vinyaya)
Butler being a black guy (pretty sure that's not normal Eurasian genetics)
Dad being in this story
The Kelp siblings gender change
Cutting the lollipop line..If the movie had been good, it would be easy to overlook, but not only am I distracted EVERY TIME Mulch is on screen, the plot is in SHAMBLES.
What the hell is Arty doing surfing, and biking, and AIMING! The boy can't shoot to save his life! (Not at 12 anyway)
WHY does he know Butler's first name? IT'S supposed to be a secret so they don't bond and he can be a more effective BODYGUARD! (Anyone who read the book knows how that went, but still)
WHAT THE HELL is this Auculos nonsense?
WHAT THE HELL is Timmy doing?! (I actually would have maybe managed if they'd done this as the dad was Arty and the kid was the 3rd!)
Why is Doctor Poe even here, they don't actually do anything with that, and it was a plot point that meant something in the book...I could keep going, but I'll just leave you with this instead..What?! Arty is a pilot too?! Okay, this might actually be in the book, but it's been a while since I read book 8.
Oh, yes, for those who don't know, they have totaled this SO badly, we COULD have had another 'HARRY POTTER' length run of these. Instead I hope it gets the axe BEFORE Percy Jackson's mashed run did... 8 books that could have been BEAUTIFUL!Actually, Netflix saved another series that was killed before it started, maybe they should buy it from Disney, cause THIS wasn't worth the time and money... They could do Percy too...

reviews.review_title: Review from someone who has not read the books
reviews.content: First off, this is a kids movie; not for grown ups. Most folks who grew up on the Artemis Fowl books is probably not in the demographic for this movie anymore. Ror someone who has never read the books, it sets up a clear introduction to the principles of the world. Movies like Bright failed in some sense because the mythos was never clear. The special effects are used well - while not being truly unique, they serve the story well. Would recommend to let your 10-15 year old kids watch the movie, and listen to what they have to say about the movie, rather than relying on original readers of the series.

reviews.review_title: What a waste of great material!

reviews.review_title: Stay back, Fandom. You don't know what you're dealing with.
reviews.content:
If you enjoyed the Artemis Fowl books, don't watch this movie. It goes beyond changing minor details or plot points. I can even gloss over the introduction of a magical item not mentioned in the books which somehow defines all of fairydom in a rather unexplained manner.
Characters are completely altered to unrecognizable, especially Butler whose first name is revealed and commonly used. Mulch Diggums is changed into a "giant dwarf." The father is not only present in the movie but plays an active role. The mother is dead. Opal Koboi is the mastermind. Foaly isn't the conspiracy theory nut. But the worst beyond worst-- Artemis himself. While the actor is superb, the character resembles nothing of the cold yet brilliant mastermind who breaks the Fairy language.
In short (sorry, Holly), go back to the books.

It shows like trying to cram 4 novels into a 90 minute show...which may be what they did.The narration is dumb. Judy Dench did an "OK" job (it's hard for her not to act well). Dialog was completely predictable...if you could follow the plot...such as it wasn't.Spoilers. Did I say the CGI was really cool? All the interactions between the humans and fairies seem to be based on some set of undefined/unexplained rules between the species. Oh, by the way, was the point of everything all part of what Artemis planned in order to get to the artifact? Not evident. And then he was surprised it was there? Ok, damage the time thingy and then you have 7 minutes until failure. The fairies break their rules by sending in a troll and then just stand around outside doing squat all. reviews.review_title: Very very disappointed... the younger actors and actresses are great but...
reviews.content: Did they even glance at the source material? Everything that made the books a wonderful tale for young adults has been stripped away and the resulting mess approved for release. I sincerely hope that in the future a directors cut will appear with all of the best parts left in.

When I saw the sloppily edited trailer for this movie, I knew it would not merit my ticket revenue at a theater. Since its early arrival on Disney + due to the pandemic, I thought I may give this movie a chance. Having not read the books, I had no expectations.
A good portion of this movie is narrated by Mulch Diggins played by Josh Gad. I don't mind a little bit of narration in a movie right before an opening title, but the narration in this movie went on for about 20 minutes, even going as far to explain events that were unfolding in front of us. The movie doesn't trust it's audience to understand what is going on.
The actor playing Artemis Fowl gave some of the flattest delivery of dialogue I have ever seen. The studio could have gotten a more charismatic performance out of a plank of wood with a happy face drawn on it.
Judi Dench played her role with what seemed like great reluctance, convincing me that Disney has black mail on her.
The movie drags on for the introduction of the main character and rushes through the plot, making it feel rushed and snail-like in its pacing at the same time.
Halfway through the movie, Artemis kidnaps a fairy to lure the rest of them to his house to find the McGuffin. Only hours later, he releases her and she gives him her unconditional friendship and help in his mission, despite being tranquilized and kidnapped by said friend earlier that same day. Trusting your captor and giving him what he wants is a pretty dangerous lesson to teach anyone, let alone a young impressionable audience that is clearly the target demographic of this movie.
Scarcely any time is spent establishing Artemis and Dovokoi as anything other than an employee/employer relationship making the tension at his near-death implausible, which ended up not mattering since Agent Short (the fairy) just brought him back to life.
The movie is sloppily edited and poorly acted that I can't spend any more energy describing it. Save yourself 2 hours and skip it.

reviews.review_title: Hard to follow and not interesting
reviews.content: I never read the books growing up but I always thought they looked interesting. I saw the commercial for this and thought it looked pretty good, so I gave it a shot. Wow. Utter garbage. I had a terrible time following the plot and it seemed like the first half of the movie was a bunch of exposition and then they suddenly fast forwarded though everything after only giving pieces of information.I felt like the movie spent so much time setting up Artemis only to suddenly and randomly introduce Holly and then spend the rest of the time focusing on her. But there was no backstory for her and I didn't know why any of the characters did anything. Also, what even was your point of Juliet?? She just showed up to make a sandwich and then be in peril. The movie would've been the same without her which stinks because I feel like she has probably a bigger part in the books.During the movie, I leaned over to my friend to ask if I'd missed something. Neither of us had any idea what was going on, and it felt like we'd watched the movie out of order. The wifi cut out with 10 minutes left and we didn't bother to try to finish the movie.I guess I'll have to check out the books for a decent story.

Okay, Disney you are a monopoly company and own literally all of the money but somehow your execs can't read? Because they clearly didnt read the book series. This is not Artemis Fowl. We would rather you NOT ruin our childhood stories than spit out money grabbing films that are all the same because you are more comcerned with a formula than you are with being accurate or making a meaninful movie.

reviews.review_title: Trying to match the brilliance of Avatar

reviews.review_title: Don't watch this if you love the books

Next time try to stick to the stories or you can also change the characters names' to make a new story.A complete waste of time.

I just can't understand for the life of me, why they had to mess with so many things and blend many books together... The original makes for a great story, what were they trying to achieve with this! reviews.review_title: Ruined a great story and potential franchise
reviews.content: There are so many basic movie faults you could pick out such as poor pacing, muddled all over the place story and a massively undeveloped set of characters but what really p***** me off is the fact this film takes so little of what makes the book so good and applies it.In the book aretemis fowl jr is clearly an actual genius and is a thief himself. They clearly showed how to be incredibly smart and he came off as an unstoppable force. In this film however he is just some stupid kid who has daddy issues. His dad is the one who steals things and deals in the underground. He is even the one to discover and find out pretty much everything about faries. The film implies AF jr is a genius but never does anything to show the audience that. He comes off as kind of an idiot damsel in distress rich kid who both gets lucky and is protected by his butler.So to sum up, this film is terrible not only on its own merits as a film but also because it ruins the story told in the first book and most unforgivably, completely ***** all over what the main character was supposed to be.The script for this film is laughably dog**** a 12 year old writing a book report on this novel could have produced a better script.

I don't normally write reviews, but I was so excited and hopeful about this movie. The novels were a delight, and my entire cadre of friends and family loved them.Unfortunately, I'm guessing that the same people who thought smashing together two of the Prydain Chronicles to make The Black Cauldron was an excellent idea must have worked on Artemis Fowl, only they didn't bother reading the novels first, no. They took the summation given to them by their twelve year old for gospel and thought they'd add in a few things while they were at it. Artemis Fowl wouldn't be caught dead surfing or using a PC instead of Apple or... well. Pretty much 95% of what he's done in this movie. Many of the amazing things Artemis did on his own are now attributed to his father, his mother is dead, Juliette is Butler's sister, he knows Butler's name *and calls him by it*, and that's just the tip of this festering iceberg. The actors obviously tried hard, and I have few general problems with their casting (aside from the fact that Juliette should have been quite a bit older). You can only work with what you're given, though, and it's clear that they weren't given much.I'd heard it wasn't very good, but my sister told me I had to watch it so that I could be as infuriated by it as she was. I did, and I therefore quite clearly am precisely that annoyed. This could have been amazing, but they missed the mark by such a wide margin that I'm fairly certain that they were at least a hundred miles away from it to start. What a miserable horror when it could have been so wonderful. It's a horrible shame and I don't recommend it to anyone who's read the novels for certain. Since I also know people who didn't read the novels who have found it equally confusing, I doubt I'd recommend it if you haven't read them, either.

A movie version of the Artemis Fowl book has been in and out of production since '01. We finally get it, and wow, this wasn't worth it. This a very disappointing adaptation. Especially surprising is that this is brought to us from Disney andA movie version of the Artemis Fowl book has been in and out of production since '01. We finally get it, and wow, this wasn't worth it. This a very disappointing adaptation. Especially surprising is that this is brought to us from Disney and director Kenneth Brannagh (Thor, Murder on the Orient Express, Cinderella).The problem is that this is a bunch of quick short scenes and characters thrown at us one after the other with very little impact. Heck, the character of Artemis' friend Juliet (played by Tamara Smart) feels like an afterthought and barely functioning character, used so sparingly despite being around the main action most of the time.I think there was a lot of trouble in editing and reshoots. There is one very clear moment of poor dub work.The barrage of scenes and characters results in a complete and utter lack of being able to become invested or relate to the characters. The only character who feels completely developed is large dwarf Mulch Diggums (Josh Gad). I feel that Disney may have felt he went best with test audiences and pushed all the attention onto him.The biggest issue is the presentation of Artemis Fowl (Ferdia Shaw) himself. He's a criminal genius in the book, but that isn't well represented here. He's still smart, but the choppy editing doesn't much make it feel like he's a master strategist. He's watered down from an antihero to a more traditional protagonist. It's Pinky, Elmyra, and the Brain all over again. The studio feels that an antihero may not sit well with parents and they water the product down. The director and/or studio also tweak Artemis' backstory, which was a mistake. (There are good movie adaptations where they change things. This just isn't one of them). They give a frustratingly basic and uninvolving story for Artemis. The characters' setup scenes are some of the dullest moments. Plus, the backstory pales in comparison to the original. The movie doesn't seem to have much faith in Artemis as he doesn't even seem to the be the main focus. Shaw also gives a rather dull performance.Last complaint: there are a couple moments that look like they might be death scenes, but I don't think they were supposed to be. It's very poorly handled.To the movie's credit, there is a good line once in a while. Gad and Judi Dench as an elf commander do a good job. Nonso Anozie as Artemis' bodyguard seemed like fun, but he just wasn't given enough attention. Being a Brannagh movie, it looks nice but it doesn't quite compare to some of his other recent works.You can avoid this one, especially if you're a fan of the book. It's not painfully bad, just barely functioning.

Being a Kenneth Branagh movie some shots looked nice and well directed AT TIMES with some decent set pieces here and there.Now the Bad. Ferdia Shaw who played Artemis Fowl had a hammy performance throughout the movie, at times he seemed too monotone and stoic and the other he seemed to be over-acting, it wasn't a terrible performance as he got a lot better during the third act but that was one of the many problems of the movie. Judy Dench also gave a weird performance with a grouchy voice, The CGI got bad real fast and this is a big budget movie mind you especially with some bad action sequences.The heist aspect of the movie took a backseat as most of it was explained through narration which took away any thrill or suspense. The villain was awful as he/she has a generic motivation to take over the world and i don't mind that but there is no backstory or any reason to be invested in the villain so it just ends up being generic movie bad guy 101 oh and he/she has a grouchy voice, i have no idea why this movie had an obsession with grouchy voices.Colin Farrell as Artemis' father had the potential to be an interesting character but as soon as you're introduced to him, he is immediately gone. Like i said the whole movie was strange, Also some scenes drag on and we are talking about a 1hr 30 minute movie here and the story never goes to interesting places and again you never care for the characters. This movie deserves 0 stars. It's not Artemis Fowl and it can't even get by on its own merits as a movie. The story has been completely changed from the books it's supposedly based on to the point where it's completely unrecognizable as Artemis Fowl in any sense. The characters have been completely changed as well. Artemis is meant to be 12-year-old criminal mastermind with the disposition of a Vulcan that was well aware of his family's criminal enterprises for his entire life and brought up to eventually take over for his father and keep their criminal empire running. He detested athletic activity and was always extremely formal, constantly wearing suits even in his down time. His father went missing when he was very young, held by the Russian mafia, and it drove his mother insane. He was left to keep everything going and at 12 he kidnapped a fairy and ransomed her for gold. Though the protagonist, in the first book Artemis was very much the villain. In this movie Artemis is clearly just a kid that is smarter than everybody else. They kept his "kid genius" trait and removed everything else. His first appearance in the film is him surfing, something the true Artemis would never have done. He's constantly seen in typical clothing you would expect a kid to wear during the first portion of the film rather than his signature suits. His mother is dead and his father is kidnapped by Opal Koboi, the reoccurring villain that was introduced in the second book and had nothing to do with the Fowl family until Artemis II foiled her schemes. Movie Artemis has an emotional outburst when he learned from a news broadcast that his father is suspected of being a criminal and denies the accusations, eventually having to be dragged away by Butler, who in the movie prefers his first name despite it being a major part of his character in the books that his first name is to remain a secret unless he's dying. Butler is the one that introduces Artemis to the reality of faeries, which is what his dad was involved in, rather than Artemis discovering faeries and dragging Butler and Juliet into it with him like in the books. All of the characters have been drastically changed in similar manners, their traits and backstories completely thrown out the window and rewritten. They're mere caricatures of the characters they're supposed to be. Even forgetting that this was supposed to be a book adaptation the movie wasn't very good. The acting is bland and the actors are always either trying too hard or not trying hard enough. The manor is beautiful from the outside but there's far too big a disconnect between the style of the exterior and the style of the interior. The voice over narration by Josh is terrible, far too raspy and often difficult to understand due to that fact. The plot of the movie is very basic and recycled from nearly every hero or spy B movie ever made. The characters are watered down stereotypes with no depth to them at all. All in all, it's just terrible. Disney wasted so much money on a movie that turned out to be complete garbage. If you're thinking about watching "Artemis Fowl" my advice would be to just watch Spy Kids or Men in Black again instead. It's basically those two movies combined in the worst ways possible and somehow both of those movies are better films than this one.
